Topic.Title: AMD unlikely to follow NVIDIA to license its graphic technologies

Message.Msg: In the best case scenario, trying to sell graphics mated to ARM will be just like trying to sell graphics mated to Intc. ARM/intc will have the bulk of the market all day long with nvda pushed to the very high end only. And ARM does not have the following in the high end/cost no objective that x86/intel has. as long as nvda is not out of linking up ARM cores, AND Tegra team laid off, sammie/aapl will just laugh at nvda's IP sales guy. They have zero reason to proliferate nvda tech and marginalize themselves. They are doing just fine on their own thank you. Ironically, brcm is a potential. brcm has their own graphics, but they will not feel threatened by using nvda graphics since nvda will never be able to assemble enough 'cheap' radios to compete in the space that brcm is aiming for. So if the price is right, brcm might bite. As for other non phone/tablet markets, there's not enough volume there for a Big Mac.

Message.Title: "Apple's New Mac Pro: What You Need to Know"
Message.Msg: "Apple's New Mac Pro: What You Need to Know" ... "Display Support The Mac Pro is made to support extreme video displays as well as providing the processing power for high-end video editing. Editing full-resolution 4K video is, at present, beyond even most workstation's capabilities, but with two AMD FirePro GPUs, the new Mac Pro will be able to do such things as "seamlessly edit full-resolution 4K video while simultaneously rendering effects in the background" while connected up to as many as three 4K ultra-HD displays." source: PC Mag Nvidia couldn't get that GPU IP in Apple's latest and greatest Desktop, now could they? lol And you know Nvidia tried to win the Mac Pro spot because you don't see that Nvidia talking head calling the Mac Pro low margin business do you? Nothing low margin about TWO (2) High End AMD FirePro GPUs to push THREE (3) 4K Ultra-HD displays is there Nvidia fans? lmao imho

Topic.Title: AMD unlikely to follow NVIDIA to license its graphic technologies

Message.Msg: "trying to sell graphics mated to ARM will be just like trying to sell graphics mated to Intc" What small minds fail to grasp is that with such a high percentage of users playing games, graphics is a major differentiator in mobile. In INTC's case in PC their differentiator was CPU and graphics is/was an afterthought. In ARM's case mali follows Intc's model of covering the basics. Just good enough won't cut it with high res displays and gaming experiences getting better every day. "for other non phone/tablet markets, there's not enough volume there" Sounds like the world has stopped rotating on it's axis in your little world. Apple, while leader today, will watch their marketshare erode over time as is the case with closed vs open systems. Billions of units are projected to ship annually in a few years and the dramatic growth will be in android. Back to the original post. The moment AMD sees NVDA gaining traction in ARM core licensing is the moment AMD's management (as the other IP leadership company in graphics) knee jerks their place into the licensing game. It's a political answer for now, anything the other guy does is bad. A smidgen of success by NVDA will change that outlook, especially for a company with such a limited potential as AMD has.

Message.Title: "Samsung’s Technology Choices Good for Intel, AMD"
Message.Msg: "Samsung’s Technology Choices Good for Intel, AMD" ... "Samsung’s decision underscores one advantage for x86 chips. Their longtime hallmark is running Windows and all the PC applications associated with that venerable operating system–a potential draw for businesses that want tablets but run their operations on Windows-based programs. But x86 chips also run Android, as a result of Intel’s work and collaboration with Google. That opens up the possibility of running thousands of Android mobile apps–many more than have been created so far Microsoft's MSFT -0.16% touch-based Windows 8 operating system. ARM chips, as things stand, can run new Android apps but not old Windows ones." ... "In London, Samsung not only introduced an Intel-based laptop called the Ativ Book 9–under that company’s Ultrabook monitor–it also announced a model called the ATIV Book 9 Lite that uses an AMD chip. It also unveiled a desktop “all in one” system called that Ativ One 5 Style that is also powered by AMD." source: wsj

Message.Title: "Vizio’s 11.6 inch, Windows 8 tablet with an AMD chip is now available for $600"
Message.Msg: "Vizio’s 11.6 inch, Windows 8 tablet with an AMD chip is now available for $600" ... "AMD’s Z-60 “Hondo” processor is a 1 GHz dual core chip with a TDP of 4.5 watts and built-in AMD Radeon HD 6250 graphics. But it seems a bit odd to ship a tablet with that processor now that AMD’s new Temash chips are available, offering better performance and lower power consumption. Still, the tablet I played with a CES in January seemed pretty responsive, so the Hondo chip might be all you really need for basic Windows 8 functionality. The tablet also features 64GB of storage, 2GB of RAM, 802.11n WiFi, Bluetooth 4.0, stereo speakers, a 2MP front-facing camera, and a 10-point capacitive multitouch touchscreen." source: liliputing

Message.Title: WSJ singing praises about Wikipad - Tegra 3 powered. Very unusual!
Message.Msg: YOU MAY HAVE bought a tablet to get more work done. But among all those office and productivity apps, you also have folder after folder filled with mobile games—the ones that you tell yourself you'll delete but end up playing for hours on end. The Wikipad is the first tablet to face facts: It makes the fun stuff the priority. Tthe Wikipad can transform into a handheld game console. It comes with a slide-on controller that adds physical thumb-sticks and an array of buttons, triggers and bumpers to let you jump, duck, fire and brake (and avoid your work email) with more precision. The Wikipad's controller is a huge improvement over the clumsy virtual controls used by most tablet games. Because the "buttons" on many touch-screen games are virtual, you often have to check that your thumbs haven't drifted off the mark when you mean to fire away. There's no fear of that with the Wikipad's controller. Better yet, you can rely on the muscle memory you developed playing "Super Mario Bros." as a kid. The controller makes the most difference with action games, like "Shadowgun" or "Grand Theft Auto: Vice City," but even simple run-and-jump titles, like "Sonic the Hedgehog," are more fun to play with real buttons and sticks. The Wikipad's wide handles also make the tablet easier to hold for extended periods of time—whether you're playing "Assassin's Creed" or watching an episode of "Game of Thrones." When it's time to get back to business, just slide off the controller and tuck it in a drawer; the Wikipad leads a double life as a mild-mannered tablet. It runs the same Android apps as two similarly sizes devices, Amazon's Kindle Fire HD and Google's GOOG Nexus 7. It has largely the same specs as the Nexus 7, too: 16GB of storage and an NVIDIA NVDA Tegra 3 quad-core processor. The Wikipad does cost about $50 more than comparable Android tablets. But that's a modest premium to pay for the hardest-playing tablet on the market. $249,

Topic.Title: WSJ singing praises about Wikipad - Tegra 3 powered. Very unusual!

Message.Msg: As far as I know, Wikipad uses the original quad-core A9 version of Tegra 3. I don't believe there is a modified version of Tegra 3 - the modified A9 is only in Tegra 4i. However, the Wikipad folks certainly can upgrade their gears in less than a year (perhaps for the holidays); ditto OUYA.
